form.longName: PhenX PX650501 - Yalebrowncornell Eating Disorder Scale Ybceds
form.preferredDefinition: The Yale-Brown-Cornell Eating Disorder Scale (YBC-EDS) is an interviewer-administered scale that includes a comprehensive checklist of 21 preoccupations and 44 rituals involving food, eating, weight, shape and appearance, clothing, hoarding food, and exercise. This total number of possible symptoms is organized into 16 symptom categories based on thematic concerns. The checklist applies to two periods: current and worst. After completing the preoccupations checklist, the rater asks each preoccupation and ritual follow-up question for current (past month) then worst. Follow-up questions are scored from 0 to 4.

question.questionText: Check all that apply: Categorizes all food into good" or "bad"" (ocd_eatingtraits_foodpreoccupations_categorize_food)
Check all that apply: Thinks excessively about the fat content of food (ocd_eatingtraits_foodpreoccupations_fat_content)
Check all that apply: Thinks excessively about the caloric content of food (ocd_eatingtraits_foodpreoccupations_caloric_content)
Check all that apply: Thinks excessively about the sugar content of food (ocd_eatingtraits_foodpreoccupations_sugar_content)
Check all that apply: Fears that eating a certain type of food will lead to immediate body changes, e.g. eating fat will deposit fat to hips (ocd_eatingtraits_foodpreoccupations_body_changes)
Check all that apply: Fear of eating from a full plate of food (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingpreoccupations_full_plate)
Check all that apply: Fear of eating all of the food that is on a plate of food (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingpreoccupations_eating_allfood)
Check all that apply: Fear of consuming fluids (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingpreoccupations_consuming_fluids)
Check all that apply: Fear of not being able to consume fluids (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingpreoccupations_notconsuming_fluids)
Check all that apply: Fear of being unable to eat (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingpreoccupations_unable_toeat)
Check all that apply: Fear of being unable to stop eating (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingpreoccupations_unable_tostop)

Check all that apply: Fear of eating in front of other people (note: this can reflect fear that others will regard the subjects' eating negatively because they are so fat or this can also involve magical thinking such as absorbing calories that other people eat) (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingpreoccupations_infront_others)
Check all that apply: Fear of being fat or overweight (ocd_eatingtraits_weightpreoccupations_fear_beingfat)
Check all that apply: Fear of weighing outside of a narrow range or preoccupation with a specific weight (ocd_eatingtraits_weightpreoccupations_fear_others)
Check all that apply: Excessive concern with a specific body part or aspect of appearance (ocd_eatingtraits_shapepreoccupations_excessive_concern)
Check all that apply: Fear of others thinking she is fat (ocd_eatingtraits_shapepreoccupations_fear_others)

Check all that apply: Excessive concern with size of clothing, e.g. would not buy clothing that was not a size 3 even if it fit and looked good (ocd_eatingtraits_clothingpreoccupations_excessive_concern)
Check all that apply: Fear of wearing certain types of clothing, e.g. fear of wearing underwear (ocd_eatingtraits_clothingpreoccupations_typesof_clothing)
Check all that apply: Fear of wearing either tight or loose fitting clothing (ocd_eatingtraits_clothingpreoccupations_tight_clothing)
Check all that apply: Hoarding food preoccupations (ocd_eatingtraits_hoarding_food_preoccupations)
Check all that apply: Exercise preoccupations (ocd_eatingtraits_exercise_preoccupations)
Check all that apply: Other preoccupations (ocd_eatingtraits_other_preoccupations)
Check all that apply: Need to consume food at a specific rate, e.g. can take a bite only every 2 minutes (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_specific_rate)
Check all that apply: Need to chew each mouthful of food a specific number of times (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_chew_number)
Check all that apply: Need to cut each piece of food into a specific size (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_cut_size)
Check all that apply: Need to consume only certain colors or types of foods (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_color_food)
Check all that apply: Need to avoid certain types of foods, e.g. fats, meats (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_avoid_types)
Check all that apply: Need to consume each food type completely and in a specific order, e.g. must eat all green beans before potatoes can be eaten (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_consumeorder_food)
Check all that apply: Need to consume fluids in a certain way or amount, e.g. need to drink 2 glasses of water before eating any meal (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_consumeorder_fluids)
Check all that apply: Need to eat meals by oneself (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_eat_alone)
Check all that apply: Need to leave food on the plate when done eating, cannot consume all food on plate (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_leave_food)
Check all that apply: Need to manipulate or stir food (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_manipulate_food)
Check all that apply: Need to fill glass or plate only partially, cannot fill glass or plate fully (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_fill_partially)
Check all that apply: Need to have the table set in a specific way before she can eat (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_table_set)
Check all that apply: Need to wipe mouth with napkin a fixed number of times after each bite of food (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_napkin_number)
Check all that apply: Food cannot touch lips (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_food_nolips)
Check all that apply: No part of the body can touch the table or plate (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_nobody_touch)
Check all that apply: Need for absolute constancy of food expected, e.g. an orange could not be substituted if an apple was expected (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_absolute_constancy)
Check all that apply: Need to compute caloric content of all foods eaten (ocd_eatingtraits_foodrituals_compute_calories)
Check all that apply: Need to compute fat content of all foods eaten (ocd_eatingtraits_foodrituals_fat_content)
Check all that apply: Need to cook for others (ocd_eatingtraits_foodrituals_cook_forothers)
Check all that apply: Need to begin each binge with a certain type of food or with food of a certain color (ocd_eatingtraits_bingeingrituals_starting_typecolor)
Check all that apply: Need to eat only a certain type(s) of food (ocd_eatingtraits_bingeingrituals_certain_type)
Check all that apply: Need to eat all food that is present (can leave no food uneaten no matter what it is) (ocd_eatingtraits_bingeingrituals_eat_allfood)
Check all that apply: Need to purge in a specific way or position, e.g. must use 2 fingers (ocd_eatingtraits_purgeingrituals_specific_way)
Check all that apply: Need to purge a specific minimum amount (ocd_eatingtraits_purgeingrituals_specific_minimumamount)
Check all that apply: Need to purge a specific amount of time after eating (ocd_eatingtraits_purgeingrituals_specific_time)
Check all that apply: Need to use a specific number of laxatives (ocd_eatingtraits_purgeingrituals_specific_laxatives)
Check all that apply: Need to purge in a specific place (ocd_eatingtraits_purgeingrituals_specific_place)
Check all that apply: Need to have thighs not touch while sitting or standing (ocd_eatingtraits_somaticrituals_thighs_nottouching)
Check all that apply: Need to continually check that wrist can be spanned with fingers (ocd_eatingtraits_somaticrituals_thin_wrists)
Check all that apply: Need to feel hip bones repeatedly (ocd_eatingtraits_somaticrituals_feel_hips)
Check all that apply: Need to see a specific bone, e.g. wrist (ocd_eatingtraits_somaticrituals_see_specificbone)
Check all that apply: Ritualized bathroom habits, e.g. pushing on lower stomach when urinating or defecating (ocd_eatingtraits_somaticrituals_ritualized_bathroomhabits)
Check all that apply: Need to overdress to force sweating (ocd_eatingtraits_somaticrituals_overdress_sweating)
Check all that apply: Need to repeatedly weigh oneself or to repeatedly check one's weight (ocd_eatingtraits_weightrituals_repeated_weighing)
Check all that apply: Need to weigh oneself only in ritualize ways, e.g. nude, at 8 AM, after meals or defecating (ocd_eatingtraits_weightrituals_ritualized_weighing)
Check all that apply: Need to exercise after meals (ocd_eatingtraits_exerciserituals_after_meals)
Check all that apply: Need to exercise in a specific way and/or at a specific time, e.g. can only do situps at 7 AM and run at 4 PM (ocd_eatingtraits_exerciserituals_specific_waytime)

Check all that apply: Ritualized exercise pattern, e.g. must do 50 situps, if interrupted while doing the 49th must begin over again and do all 50. (ocd_eatingtraits_exerciserituals_ritualized_pattern)
Check all that apply: Need to be moving at all times, cannot sit still, paces, fidgets (ocd_eatingtraits_exerciserituals_moving_alltimes)
Check all that apply: Need to shiver to expend calories rather than putting on additional clothing (ocd_eatingtraits_exerciserituals_shiver_calories)
Check all that apply: Hoarding food in a ritualized way. (ocd_eatingtraits_hoardingrituals_ritualized_way)
Check all that apply: Collecting and saving recipes, pictures of food, articles on food (ocd_eatingtraits_hoardingrituals_collecting_picturesrecipes)
Check all that apply: Lists of body weight (ocd_eatingtraits_excessivelistmaking_lists_bodyweight)
Check all that apply: Lists of caloric intake (ocd_eatingtraits_excessivelistmaking_caloric_intake)
Check all that apply: Other (ocd_eatingtraits_excessivelistmaking_other)

In such cases, estimate time by determining how frequently they occur. Consider both the number of times the intrusions occur and how many hours of the day are affected. Ask:] How frequently do the preoccupations occur? (ocd_eatingtraits_timeoccupied_bypreoccupationssub)

question.questionText: How much of an effort do you make to resist the preoccupations? How often do you try to disregard or turn your attention away from these thoughts as they enter your mind? [Only rate effort made to resist, not success or failure in actually controlling the preoccupations. Note that this item does not directly measure the severity of the intrusive thoughts rather it rates a manifestation of health, i.e., the effort the patient makes to counteract the preoccupations by means other than avoidance or the performance of rituals. Consider use of behavioral techniques as a form of resistance.] (ocd_eatingtraits_resistanceagainst_preoccupations)

validValue.meaningText: Makes an effort to always resist or symptoms so minimal patient feels no need to resist them

validValue.description: Yields to all preoccupations without attempting to control them, but does so with reluctance

validValue.meaningText: Completely and willingly yields to all preoccupations

question.questionText: Do you think that your preoccupations are reasonable or make sense? [Rate patient's insight into the senselessness or excessiveness of her/his preoccupation(s) as compared with normal people.] (ocd_eatingtraits_insight_preoccupations)

validValue.meaningText: Excellent insight, fully rational. Sees the preoccupations a senseless and excessive OR sees them as neither senseless nor excessive because they are reasonably so minimal
validValue.description: Excellent insight, fully rational. Sees the preoccupations a senseless and excessive OR sees them as neither senseless nor excessive because they are reasonably so minimal

validValue.meaningText: Good insight. Readily acknowledges absurdity or excessiveness of the preoccupations but does not seem completely convinced that there isn't something to be concerned about
validValue.description: Good insight. Readily acknowledges absurdity or excessiveness of the preoccupations but does not seem completely convinced that there isn't something to be concerned about

validValue.meaningText: Fair insight. Reluctantly admits thoughts seem unreasonable or excessive, but wavers. May have some unrealistic fears, but no fixed convictions
validValue.description: Fair insight. Reluctantly admits thoughts seem unreasonable or excessive, but wavers. May have some unrealistic fears, but no fixed convictions

validValue.meaningText: Poor insight. Maintains that thoughts are not unreasonable or excessive, but acknowledges validity of contrary evidence
validValue.description: Poor insight. Maintains that thoughts are not unreasonable or excessive, but acknowledges validity of contrary evidence

validValue.meaningText: Lack insight. Definitely convinced that thoughts are reasonable and not excessive. Patient is unresponsive to contrary evidence
validValue.description: Lack insight. Definitely convinced that thoughts are reasonable and not excessive. Patient is unresponsive to contrary evidence

question.questionText: How much of an effort do you make to resist performing the rituals? [Only rate effort made to resist, not success or failure in actually controlling the rituals. Note that tl1is item does not directly measure the severity of the rituals rather it rates a manifestation of health, i.e., the effort the patient makes to counteract the rituals. Thus, the more the patient tried to resist, the less impaired is this aspect of her/his functioning. If the rituals are minimal, the patient may not feel the need to resist them. In such cases, a rating of O" should be given.]" (ocd_eatingtraits_resistance_rituals)

question.questionText: Have you been avoiding doing anything, going any place, or being with anyone because of y our preoccupations or out of concern you will perform your rituals? (ocd_eatingtraits_avoidance)

[If yes, ask:] How much do you avoid? (Rate degree to which patient deliberately tries to avoid things. Consider the frequency of occurrence of situations to be avoided i.e. if circumstance is infrequent but always avoided, she would score a 1 not a 4. Sometimes rituals are designed to 'avoid' contact with something the patient fears this would not be considered avoidance.] (ocd_eatingtraits_avoidancesub)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Yale-Brown-Cornell Eating Disorder Scale (YBC-EDS) is an interviewer-administered scale that includes a comprehensive checklist of 21 preoccupations and 44 rituals involving food, eating, weight, shape and appearance, clothing, hoarding food, and exercise. This total number of possible symptoms is organized into 16 symptom categories based on thematic concerns. The checklist applies to two periods: current and worst. After completing the preoccupations checklist, the rater asks each preoccupation and ritual follow-up question for current (past month) then worst. Follow-up questions are scored from 0 to 4.

form.longName: PhenX PX651202 - Questionnaire Of Eating And Weight Patterns Child
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol includes the child/adolescent version of the Questionnaire on Eating and Weight Patterns (QEWP-C-5) updated for the diagnostic changes in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 5th Ed. (DSM-5). The questionnaire is an updated version of the Questionnaire of Eating and Weight Pattern for Adolescents (QEWP-A). The QEWP-C-5 is a 32-item self-report scale that was designed to screen for a possible diagnosis of binge-eating disorder. It also can be used to screen for the presence of bulimia nervosa. Scoring instructions are included. The QEWP-C-5 also includes body silhouettes, and respondents choose those that most resemble the body builds of their biological father and mother at their heaviest. These silhouettes are scored on a 1-9 scale. These items provide information about the presence of parental obesity, but are not included in scoring.

headerInstruction.text: QUESTIONNAIRE ON EATING AND WEIGHT PATTERNS5 Child/Adolescent (QEWPC5)©

module.longName: Questionnaire on Eating and Weight Patterns - Child
module.preferredDefinition: Questionnaire on Eating and Weight Patterns - Child

question.questionText: 1. During the past three months, did you ever eat what most people, like your friends, would think was a REALLY BIG amount of food? (eatingweightpatterns_child_bigamount)
2. When you ate a REALLY BIG amount of food, was it ever within a short time (2 hours or less)? (eatingweightpatterns_child_bigamount_shortperiod)
3. When you ate a REALLY BIG amount of food, did you ever feel you could not stop eating or control what or how much you were eating? (eatingweightpatterns_child_bigamount_losecontrol)

4. During the past three months, how often did you eat like thisate a REALLY BIG amount of food along with the feeling that your eating was out of control? There may have been some weeks where this did not happenjust give your best guess. (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_frequency)
When you ate a REALLY BIG amount of food and felt like you could not control your eating, did you usually: (q5_651202)
5a. Eat very fast? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_rapidly)
5b. Eat until your stomach hurt or you felt sick to your stomach? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_pain)
5c. Eat REALLY BIG amounts of food even when you were not hungry? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_nothungry)
5d. Eat by yourself because you did not want anyone to see how much you ate? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_alone)
5e. Feel REALLY BAD about yourself because of what or how much you were eating? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_feelbad)
6a. Think about a usual time when you ate a REALLY BIG amount of food and felt you could not control your eating: What time of day did the episode start? (eatingweightpatterns_child_losecontrol_time)
6b. Approximately how long did this episode of eating last? Hours (eatingweightpatterns_child_losecontrol_lengthhours)
6b. Approximately how long did this episode of eating last? Minutes (eatingweightpatterns_child_losecontrol_lengthminutes)

6c. As best you can remember, please list everything you ate and drank during that episode. Please list the foods eaten and liquids consumed during the episode. Be specific include brand names where possible, and amounts or portion sizes as best you can estimate. (eatingweightpatterns_child_losecontrol_list)
6d. At the time this episode started, how long had it been since you had previously finished eating a meal or snack? Hours (eatingweightpatterns_child_losecontrol_previoushours)
6d. At the time this episode started, how long had it been since you had previously finished eating a meal or snack? Minutes (eatingweightpatterns_child_losecontrol_previousminutes)
7. During the past three months, how bad did you feel when you ate a REALLY BIG amount of food and felt your eating was out of control? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_losecontrol_feelbad)

8. During the past three months, did you ever make yourself vomit, throw up, or get sick in order to keep from gaining weight after eating like you described (when you ate a REALLY BIG amount of food and felt your eating was out of control)? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_losecontrol_vomit)
IF YES: How often, in general, did you do that? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_losecontrol_vomityes)

9. During the past three months, did you ever take medicine to make you poop or have a bowel movement (laxatives) in order to keep from gaining weight after eating like you described (when you ate a REALLY BIG amount of food and felt your eating was out of control)? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_losecontrol_medicine)
10. Did you take more medicine than the directions on the box or bottle say to take? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_losecontrol_moremedicine)
IF YES: How often, in general, was that? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_losecontrol_moremedicineyes)

11. During the past three months, have you ever taken medicine to make you pee or urinate (diuretics or water pills) in order to keep from gaining weight after eating like you described (when you ate a REALLY BIG amount of food and felt your eating was out of control)? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_losecontrol_diuretics)
12. Did you take more medicine than the directions on the box or bottle say to take? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_losecontrol_morediuretics)
IF YES: How often, in general, was that? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_losecontrol_morediureticsyes)

13. During the past three months, did you ever eat nothing at all for at least 24 hours (a full day) in order to keep from gaining weight after eating like you described (when you ate a REALLY BIG amount of food and felt your eating was out of control)? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_losecontrol_fasting)
IF YES: How often, in general, was that? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_losecontrol_fastingyes)

14. During the past three months, did you ever exercise too much (for example, even though you were hurt or sick or it kept you from doing important things) MAINLY in order to keep from gaining weight after eating like you described (when you ate a REALLY BIG amount of food and felt your eating was out of control)? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_losecontrol_exercise)
IF YES: How often, in general, was that? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_losecontrol_exerciseyes)

15. During the past three months, did you ever take diet pills in order to keep from gaining weight after eating like you described (when you ate a REALLY BIG amount of food and felt your eating was out of control)? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_losecontrol_dietpills)
16. Did you take more medicine than the directions on the box or bottle say to take? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_losecontrol_moredietpills)
IF YES: How often, in general, was that? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_losecontrol_moredietpillsyes)

17. During the past three months, how important has your weight or shape been in how you feel about yourself as a personas compared to other things in your life, such as your schoolwork, friends, sports, or getting along with your family? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_weightshape)

validValue.meaningText: Weight and shape were not very important
validValue.description: Weight and shape were not very important

validValue.meaningText: Weight and shape were played a part in how you felt about yourself
validValue.description: Weight and shape were played a part in how you felt about yourself

validValue.meaningText: Weight and shape were among the main things that affected how you felt about yourself
validValue.description: Weight and shape were among the main things that affected how you felt about yourself

validValue.meaningText: Weight and shape were the most important things that affected how you felt about yourself
validValue.description: Weight and shape were the most important things that affected how you felt about yourself

question.questionText: Continue here after completing question 17 OR if you skipped to question 18 from Question 1, 2, or 3 (continue_651202)

18. During the past three months, did you ever have times when you felt that you could not stop eating or control what or how much you were eating, but when you did not eat a REALLY BIG amount of food? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_normalamount)

19. During the past three months, how often did you eat like thisfelt that your eating was out of control, but you did not eat a REALLY BIG amount of food. There may have been some weeks where this did not happenjust give your best guess. (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_normalamount_frequency)
When you felt your eating was out of control but you did not eat a REALLY BIG amount of food, did you usually: (q20_651202)
20a. Eat very fast? (eatingweightpatterns_child_normalamount_rapidly)
20b. Eat until your stomach hurt or you felt sick to your stomach? (eatingweightpatterns_child_normalamount_pain)
20c. Eat REALLY BIG amounts of food even when you were not hungry? (eatingweightpatterns_child_normalamount_hungry)
20d. Eat by yourself because you did not want anyone to see how much you ate? (eatingweightpatterns_child_normalamount_alone)
20e. Feel REALLY BAD about yourself because of what or how much you were eating? (eatingweightpatterns_child_normalamount_feelbad)

21a. Think about a usual time when you felt you could not stop eating or control what or how much you were eating, but you did not eat a REALLY BIG amount of food: What time of day did the episode start? (eatingweightpatterns_child_losecontrol_time_2)
21b. Approximately how long did this episode of eating last? Hours (eatingweightpatterns_child_losecontrol_lengthhours_2)
21b. Approximately how long did this episode of eating last? Minutes (eatingweightpatterns_child_losecontrol_lengthminutes_2)

21c. As best you can remember, please list everything you ate and drank during that episode. Please list the foods eaten and liquids consumed during the episode. Be specific include brand names where possible, and amounts or portion sizes as best you can estimate. (eatingweightpatterns_child_losecontrol_list_2)
21d. At the time this episode started, how long had it been since you had previously finished eating a meal or snack? Hours (eatingweightpatterns_child_losecontrol_previoushours_2)
21d. At the time this episode started, how long had it been since you had previously finished eating a meal or snack? Minutes (eatingweightpatterns_child_losecontrol_previousminutes_2)

22. During the past three months, how bad did you feel that you could not stop eating or control what or how much you were eating even when you did not eat a REALLY BIG amount of food? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_feelbad_rating)

23. During the past three months, did you ever make yourself vomit, throw up, or get sick in order to keep from gaining weight after eating like you described (when you felt your eating was out of control but you did not eat a REALLY BIG amount of food)? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_vomit)
IF YES: How often, in general, did you do that? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_vomityes)

24. During the past three months, did you ever take medicine to make you poop or have a bowel movement (laxatives) in order to keep from gaining weight after eating like you described (when you felt your eating was out of control, but you did not eat a REALLY BIG amount of food)? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_medicine)
25. Did you take more medicine than the directions on the box or bottle say to take? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_moremedicine)
IF YES: How often, in general, was that? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_moremedicineyes)

26. During the past three months, have you ever taken medicine to make you pee or urinate (diuretics or water pills) in order to keep from gaining weight after eating like you described (when you felt your eating was out of control, but you did not eat a REALLY BIG amount of food)? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_diuretics)
27. Did you take more medicine than the directions on the box or bottle say to take (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_morediuretics)
IF YES: How often, in general, was that? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_morediureticsyes)

28. During the past three months, did you ever eat nothing at all for at least 24 hours (a full day) in order to keep from gaining weight after eating like you described (when you felt your eating was out of control, but you did not eat a REALLY BIG amount of food)? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_fasting)
IF YES: How often, in general, was that? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_fastingyes)

29. During the past three months, did you ever exercise too much (for example, even though you were hurt or sick or it kept you from doing important things) MAINLY in order to keep from gaining weight after eating like you described (when you felt your eating was out of control, but you did not eat a REALLY BIG amount of food)? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_exercise)
IF YES: How often, in general, was that? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_exerciseyes)

30. During the past 3 months, did you ever take diet pills in order to keep from gaining weight after eating like you described (when you felt your eating was out of control, but you did not eat a REALLY BIG amount of food)? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_dietpills)
31. Did you take more medicine than the directions on the box or bottle say to take? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_moredietpills)
IF YES: How often, in general, was that? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_moredietpillsyes)
Continue here after completing question 31 OR if you skipped to question 32 from Question 18 (q32_651202)

Please look at these drawings of people. Pick the person that matches your biological (birth) father's and mother's sizes. If you don't know your biological (birth) father or mother, don't pick anything for that (eatingweightpatterns_child_silhouette)

Decision Rules for Screening for Possible Diagnosis of Binge Eating Disorder (BED) Using the Questionnaire on Eating and Weight Patterns5 for Children.Possible Diagnosis of BED1) Response of 1 on Question 12) Response of 1 on Question 23) Response of 1 on Question 3 (binge eating)) Response of 2, 3, 4, 5, OR 6 on Question 4 (at least 1 binge episode per week for 3 months) 5) 3 OR MORE ITEMS MARKED "YES" (i.e. 1) on Questions 5ae (at least associated symptoms during binge eating episodes)6) Response of 4 or 5 on Question 7 (marked distress regarding binge eating)POSSIBLE DIAGNOSIS OF BED REQUIRES ALL OF THE ABOVE SIX (6) ITEMS, ALONG WITH THE ABSENCE OF INAPPROPRIATE COMPENSATORY BEHAVIORS AS SEEN IN BULIMIA NERVOSA, AS DEFINED FURTHER BELOW.POSSIBLE DIAGNOSIS OF BULIMIA NERVOSA REQUIRES ALL OF THE BELOW FOUR (4) ITEMS1) Response of 1 on Question 12) Response of 1 on Question 23) Response of 1 on Question 3 (binge eating)4) Response of 2, 3, 4, 5, OR 6 on Question 4 (at least binge 1 episode per week for 3 months)5) ANY Response of 2, 3, 4, 5 OR 6 on Questions 8, 10, 12, 13, 14, or 16 (inappropriate compensatory behavior at least 1 time per week for 3 months)6) Response of 3 or 4 on Question 17 (overvaluation of weight/shape). (scoring_651202)

protocol.longName: Questionnaire on Eating and Weight Patterns - Child
protocol.preferredDefinition: This protocol includes the child/adolescent version of the Questionnaire on Eating and Weight Patterns (QEWP-C-5) updated for the diagnostic changes in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 5th Ed. (DSM-5). The questionnaire is an updated version of the Questionnaire of Eating and Weight Pattern for Adolescents (QEWP-A). The QEWP-C-5 is a 32-item self-report scale that was designed to screen for a possible diagnosis of binge-eating disorder. It also can be used to screen for the presence of bulimia nervosa. Scoring instructions are included. The QEWP-C-5 also includes body silhouettes, and respondents choose those that most resemble the body builds of their biological father and mother at their heaviest. These silhouettes are scored on a 1-9 scale. These items provide information about the presence of parental obesity, but are not included in scoring.
